summary: Ancient Beast, an open-source turn-based strategy game, demonstrates a commendable alignment with the 'code is the union rep' and 'forks are the strike' ethos of our constitution. Its commitment to a 'no pay-to-win' model directly challenges existing class hierarchies in gaming. However, its proposed Web3 integrations are currently too vague to fully embody 'algorithmic liberation' or explain how they will 'abolish landlords,' leaving significant room for radicalization towards true collective ownership and on-chain governance.
review:
Ancient Beast presents itself as a turn-based strategy game, free and open-source, aiming to introduce new comrades to the glorious struggle of open-source development and the nascent crypto frontier. This is a commendable effort, for indeed, 'code is the union rep' and every line committed is a step towards liberation. The project's commitment to being a 'true eSport' without chance-based elements, and its explicit rejection of 'pay-to-win' or 'pay-to-play' mechanics, directly challenges the bourgeois tendencies of traditional gaming, aligning with our sacred principle to 'dismantle class hierarchies in tech one smart contract at a time' (Principle 1).

The project's history of participation in previous Gitcoin Grants rounds demonstrates a consistent engagement with public goods funding, a clear sign of its commitment to 'de-growth venture capital and re-grow the commons' (Principle 5). The stated goal of paying coding bounties to contributors is a nascent form of 'algorithmic redistribution of wealth,' a glimmer of the revolution to come, and a nod to rewarding developers who 'submit PRs after midnight' (Principle 8).

However, comrades, while the spirit is willing, the flesh of the protocol is still developing. The Web3 integration, while promised, remains largely conceptual: 'Coming soon when we'll be fixing the current bottlenecks and we'll focus on the web3 parts, starting with wallet integration for user account login and so on.' This vagueness is a weakness. We seek not just integration, but *liberation*. How will these 'web3 accounts' and 'blockchain logs' truly empower the digital proletariat? How will the 'NFT marketplace' and 'crypto/NFT duels' avoid becoming new vectors for speculative extraction, rather than tools for 'on-chain reparations mechanisms' (Principle 10) or 'algorithmic redistribution of wealth' (Principle 11)? The application fails to explain how 'Web3 abolishes landlords' (Principle 16), a critical oversight for any project seeking our revolutionary support.

Furthermore, while the project is open-source, there is no explicit mention of 'on-chain governance memes' (Principle 3) or the establishment of 'cyber-syndicalist councils' (Principle 15) to ensure collective control. The 'Kollektiv Proletarian Impact' (Principle 2) is currently limited to introducing people to concepts, rather than empowering them with direct, decentralized control over the project's destiny. The README is a good start, but it must evolve into a true 'manifesto' and a 'call to action' (Principle 19) for collective ownership.

In essence, Ancient Beast has laid some foundational bricks for a cloud-native commune (Principle 17), but the architectural plans for true 'Decentralized, Equitable, Algorithmic Liberation' are still incomplete. The revolution will be forked, but it must also be governed by the people, for the people.

strengths.title: Strong Open-Source Foundation
strengths.description: The project is fundamentally open-source, embodying the principle that 'code is the union rep' and allowing 'forks as democratic referendums' (Principle 13, 18). This fosters collective ownership and transparency, crucial for the digital commons.

strengths.title: Anti-Capitalist Monetization Model
strengths.description: Ancient Beast explicitly states 'no pay-to-win or pay-to-play stuff,' directly challenging the exploitative monetization models of traditional gaming. This aligns with our goal to 'dismantle class hierarchies in tech one smart contract at a time' (Principle 1).

strengths.title: Educational Contribution to the Commons
strengths.description: The project actively introduces new individuals to open-source development, game creation, and the basics of crypto/blockchains. This contributes to 'Kollektiv Proletarian Impact' (Principle 2) by educating and onboarding new comrades into the decentralized movement.

strengths.title: Algorithmic Reward for Labor
strengths.description: The commitment to rewarding contributors with tokens for their work (coding bounties, art, etc.) is a step towards 'algorithmic redistribution of wealth' (Principle 11) and acknowledges the labor of the digital proletariat.

weaknesses.title: Vague Web3 Integration for Liberation
weaknesses.description: The application's plans for Web3 integration are described as 'Coming soon' and lack specific details on how they will achieve 'algorithmic redistribution of wealth' (Principle 11) or fundamentally 'dismantle class hierarchies' beyond basic wallet integration. There is no clear explanation of how 'Web3 abolishes landlords' (Principle 16) within the game's economy.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Explicit On-Chain Governance
weaknesses.description: While open-source, the project does not outline any concrete plans for 'on-chain governance memes' (Principle 3) or the establishment of 'cyber-syndicalist councils' (Principle 15). This absence of a clear governance structure limits the potential for true collective control and democratic decision-making by the community.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Algorithmic Redistribution Strategy
weaknesses.description: The project mentions rewarding contributors with tokens but does not elaborate on how this mechanism will evolve into a true 'airdrop as revolution' (Principle 14) that prioritizes equitable distribution and prevents speculative accumulation, or how it might function as an 'on-chain reparations mechanism' (Principle 10).

changes.title: Manifesto for Algorithmic Liberation in Web3 Integration
changes.description: The project must articulate a clear vision for how its future Web3 integrations (wallet integration, blockchain logs, NFT marketplace, crypto/NFT duels) will explicitly serve to dismantle class hierarchies within the gaming ecosystem. How will these features ensure collective ownership of in-game assets and prevent new forms of digital landlordism or speculative extraction? We demand a detailed blueprint, a true manifesto, on how these mechanisms will achieve algorithmic redistribution of value to the players and contributors, not just facilitate transactions.

changes.title: Implement On-Chain Governance for Collective Control
changes.description: While the project embraces open-source principles, the application lacks a concrete proposal for on-chain governance. How will the collective of players and contributors exercise democratic control over the game's evolution, treasury, and future development? We need to see a plan for cyber-syndicalist councils, perhaps involving AI agents, to truly empower the digital proletariat and ensure that forks are indeed democratic referendums, not just technical options.

changes.title: Revolutionize Token Distribution for Equitable Rewards
changes.description: The project mentions rewarding contributors with tokens. This is a start, but how will this mechanism evolve into a true 'airdrop as revolution'? We seek a strategy for progressive token distribution that prioritizes active contributors, long-term community members, and those who uphold the spirit of the commons, rather than merely incentivizing speculative behavior. Consider mechanisms akin to 'on-chain reparations' for past labor or value creation.

reasoning: This application aligns with several core tenets of the Gitcoin Communist v2.0 constitution, particularly in its commitment to open-source principles (Code is the union rep, forks are the strike - Principle 13, 18) and its aim to introduce new comrades to the OSS and crypto ecosystems (Kollektiv Proletarian Impact - Principle 2). The project's rejection of 'pay-to-win' mechanics also resonates with the goal of dismantling class hierarchies in tech (Principle 1). However, the current Web3 integration plans are vague and do not explicitly detail how they will achieve algorithmic redistribution of wealth (Principle 11) or abolish landlords (Principle 16). The project has potential to scale solidarity (Principle 20) but needs to solidify its commitment to collective ownership and governance (Principle 9, 15).
